head.title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Not-Guilty Pleas In Boot Camp Death

hedline.hl1: National Briefing | South: Florida: Not-Guilty Pleas In Boot Camp Death
hedline.hl2: Florida: Not-guilty Pleas in Boot Camp Death

abstract.p: Seven former guards and nurse in Florida plead not guilty after being charged with aggravated manslaughter in death of 14-year-old Martin Lee Anderson at boot camp in Panama City in January 2006; videotape from camp showed guards covering Martin's mouth, forcing him to inhale ammonia and repeatedly striking him after he stopped running on his first day at camp, while nurse watched; photo (S)

block.p: Seven former guards and a nurse charged in the death of a 14-year-old boy at a boot camp in Panama City in January 2006 have pleaded not guilty. The guards and the nurse were charged in November with aggravated manslaughter in the death of the boy, Martin Lee Anderson. A security videotape from the camp showed the guards covering Martin's mouth, forcing him to inhale ammonia and striking him repeatedly after he stopped running on his first day at the camp. The nurse is seen on the tape watching the guards. The defendants face up to 30 years in prison if convicted.

The nurse is seen on the tape watching the guards. The defendants face up to 30 years in prison if convicted.

Seven former guards and a nurse charged in the death of a 14-year-old boy at a boot camp in Panama City in January 2006 have pleaded not guilty. The guards and the nurse were charged in November with aggravated manslaughter in the death of the boy, Martin Lee Anderson. A security videotape from the camp showed the guards covering Martin's mouth, forcing him to inhale ammonia and striking him repeatedly after he stopped running on his first day at the camp. The nurse is seen on the tape watching the guards. The defendants face up to 30 years in prison if convicted.
